Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 11:17PM Toonies wrote: Mom2acat.....I believe that I have had nerve damage in my arm from rads.  Last year I had pain in my right forearm and went for MRI.  Dx. as a lesion.  Had rads.  Well not only do I now have limited range of motion of the arm, I developed lymphedema as this was the arm that I had my node resection on.  I can only rotate my arm 45 degrees, can't even get a fork to my mouth.  Ticks me off but I don't have pain anymore, just kind of a useless hand!  Hopefully your pain stays away!  Glad you are feeling better                                           Toonies
Posts.Title: Nerve damage from radiation mom2acat Toonies

Posts.Content: May 11, 2009 10:55PM Toonies wrote: Wendy,      I have walked down your road before and have a very strong opinion on your question.  Zeloda is a magnificent medication and also very effective.  Are you aware that it is 5 FU in pill form?  5FU is a chemo. drug.  Zeloda has been by far the least invasive of all the chemo drugs I have been on and I had very good results with it.  I stayed on Zeloda for approx. 2.5 years and really beat the beast back.  My T.M.s were way down and then the med. stopped working for me.  Then of course we tried other hormaonals and when they didn't work, on my way to I.V. chemos.  The Zeloda allowed me to maintain my normal lifestyle without weekly visits to the Onc. for I.V. meds.  I continued to travel at will with my dose of oral medications.  Now, I am not saying that there were no side effects, but they were relatively minimal.  Sometimes the pills didn't sit well in my stomach and I had a good dose of hand foot syndrome but it was a trade off.  I am now on I.V. meds. 3 wks. on 1 wk. off.  The side effects can be numerous and if I want to travel I have to make arrangements with another physician. [Which isn't always easy]  So, needless to say, I am a great cheerleader for Zeloda and wish that it were still effective for me.  Life would be much simpler.  If you need to go on any med. that would win my vote.  Good luck with everything and I hope you get a long time out of the Zeloda or go NED before that.  Keep your chin up.                                                                          Toonies
Posts.Title: stg iv; from horm. trt to chemo wendy1356 Toonies

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 11:26AM Toonies wrote: Hi Towens88,  The hot flashes will eventually go away but you probably have some distance to go with them as you were dx. at a young age with plenty of estrogen in your body.  A few tips: put a small fan at your bedside and direct it from your neck down,  when you feel a flash starting run your hands under ice cold water.  I'm sorry for you because I went thru it to and I know how unpleasant it can be.  You're going to have to just bite the bullet and try to deal.  I used to count them and I think that one day I got at least 15.  Fortunately they have now subsided, but they darn well should as I am now 57.  Good luck and try and stay cool               Toonies
Posts.Title: Hot flashes! towens88 Curlylocks

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2008 07:48PM Toonies wrote: Hi Mama3birds,    I am currently on Abraxane and developed a rash on my abdomen and in the back of my hairline.  It was very itchy and flaky!  Went to a dermatologist and he said that rashes commonly occur on chemo.  He gave me a script for a creme called Lidex Creme 0.05% to be uused 2x's per day.  It worked amazingly well and the rash was gone in 3 days.  Every now and again I get some itching, use the creme and it goes away.  May not be the same kind of rash but it can't hurt to try it.  The rash was never on my hands.  Good luck to your Mom, hope this works.                                                                               Toonies
Posts.Title: Abraxane Side Effects (rash) mama3birds mama3birds

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 05:43PM Toonies wrote: All out there on Xeloda.....when the feet and hands get bad I would refrigerate Aloe Vera lotion and apply.  Sooooo soothing!!

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 06:34PM Toonies wrote: LuAnn........Just saw the onc. yesterday, again complaining about the foot neuropathy.  She recommended, in addition to taking B6 3xs/day to take a complex B vit.  Don't know if it will be helpful but I sure am going to try it.  I will also give the tonic a whirl.  Ya know, this damn disease sucks!  Had 1 mo. off chemo and thought "This is great!"  "I"ll be able to get alot done"   Well, when you walk like a drunk and feel unsteady, doing ain't so easy!  Oh well, one thing that I have learned is if it ain't one thing it's another!                  Toonies
Posts.Title: Neuropathy ideas LuAnnH mthomp2020

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 06:20PM Toonies wrote: Robin.......I read your message with great interest.  I too went for a consult with an intervention radiologist yesterday.  It's amazing!  He stated verbatim what your radiologist said.  One point differed.  He said I could not have chemo. concurrently with the Theraspheres and that I would have to interrupt treatment for about 8 weeks, per protocol.  However, he did say that the protocol for Sirspheres may be differant and he is going to look into it.  My situation is pretty much the samr as yours.  I have mets. to both lobes of the liver and will have to have it done twice.  We are aiming to start angiogram etc. at the end of June.  My daughter is getting married the 20th of June and I just wanted to get beyond that.  So up to that point, more chemo.  Please keep us up to date on your progress.  Good luck with everything!!                          Toonies
